content:
The philosophical and existential themes in Albert Camus' novel The Stranger include the absurdity of human existence, the meaninglessness of life, the inevitability of death, the rejection of societal norms and values, and the importance of individual freedom.

The protagonist of the novel, Meursault, is an absurd character who refuses to conform to the expectations of society. He is indifferent to the death of his mother and kills an Arab man without any apparent motive, which highlights the meaningless of life and the lack of a moral compass.

Meursault's trial and condemnation to death also underscore the powerlessness of the individual in the face of societal norms and values. The novel suggests that societal rules are often arbitrary and that the individual will always be trapped in a cycle of meaningless existence.

Camus also explores the human condition and the search for meaning in a world devoid of purpose. Meursault's acceptance of his fate and his final words, "I had only to wish that there be a large crowd of spectators the day of my execution and that they greet me with cries of hate," highlight the acceptance of the inevitability of death and the embrace of individual freedom.

Overall, The Stranger confronts readers with the fundamental existential questions of life, death, and the search for meaning, ultimately suggesting that there are no easy answers and that individuals must find their own paths in a world devoid of meaning.
